qas.question: What field did Von Neuman establish?
What is the distinction of continuous geometry?

answers.text: instead of the dimension of a subspace being in a discrete set 0, 1, ..., n, it can be an element of the unit interval

qas.question: What was the first example of continuous geometry?

answers.text: projections of the hyperfinite type II factor

context: Von Neumann founded the field of <a0_0>continuous geometry.<a0_0/> It followed his path-breaking work on rings of operators. In mathematics, continuous geometry is an analogue of complex projective geometry, where <a1_0>instead of the dimension of a subspace being in a discrete set 0, 1, ..., n, it can be an element of the unit interval<a1_0/> [0,1]. Von Neumann was motivated by his discovery of von Neumann algebras with a dimension function taking a continuous range of dimensions, and the first example of a continuous geometry other than projective space was the <a2_0>projections of the hyperfinite type II factor<a2_0/>.
